awd_titl_txt: Reconfigurable All-Digital CMOS Frequency Synthesizers for Cognitive and Milimeter-Wave Radios
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless communication has had an immeasurable economic, societal and scientific impact worldwide. However, with the recent explosion of smartphones and tablets, and the expected emergence of new types of networks such as sensor swarms and the internet of things, the current model of licensed access to spectrum being appears increasingly unviable. There is currently active research into two complementary solutions: (1) spectrum sharing cognitive radios and (2) wireless networks based on dense, short-range millimeter-wave links. The development of highly reconfigurable, power-efficient radios is critical to the long term success of these technologies. This proposal addresses a critical circuit-level challenge by developing design techniques for agile, spectrally pure and reconfigurable "universal" frequency synthesizers. 
Intellectual Merit:  Compared to analog-based frequency synthesizers commonly used in current radios, all-digital frequency synthesizers are less sensitive to the analog-imperfections of nanoscale CMOS, are highly reconfigurable and can be rapidly ported across technology nodes, and are therefore promising candidates for universal frequency synthesis.  However, the design of widely tunable oscillators, high-resolution/high-linearity time-to-digital converters and the interface between the two pose obstacles to the successful realization of all-digital frequency synthesizers. Several new concepts and techniques are proposed to address these challenges. These include multi-resonance mode switched and phase-change via-reconfigurable oscillators, time-to-digital converters with in situ statistical linearization, real-time digital assistance for the analog components of the synthesizer and built-in monitoring, adaptation and self-test circuitry. A CMOS prototype will be designed and fabricated to validate these concepts. 
Broader Impact  The outcomes of this research will fill a critical need towards the realization of practical devices for use in future wireless systems using advanced spectral access technologies. The outcomes will also fill a pressing near-term need for prototypes that form the basis of pilot testbeds. The educational components of this proposal include scientific publications, public relations, mentoring, and outreach through various programs conducted by the CMU Gelfand Center for Service Learning and Outreach; these programs include the Moving 4th into Engineering and Summer Engineering Experience for girls in middle school programs and other outreach programs for women and other underrepresented groups. The outcomes of this research will be integrated into various classes taught by the PI. A new capstone course on Mixed-Signal Integrated Circuit Design will be developed. The PI will continue to recruit and train undergraduate students through the the Summer Research Experience Program Carnegie Mellon, with a special focus on attracting students from minority groups and institutions.

por.por_cntn:
Wireless communication has had an immeasurable economic, societal and scientific impact worldwide. However, with the continuing explosion of smartphones, tablets, sensor swarms, the internet of things etc., worldwide mobile data traffic is expected to exceed 66,000 PB/month (petabytes) in 2022, up from 94 PB/month in 2010.  While almost all commercial wireless communication currently occupies frequency bands below 6 GHz, it is now widely accepted that the exploitation of new spectrum in the 20-100 GHz range (roughly called millimeter-wave) is the only viable approach that can meet this projected demand. However, compared to sub-6 GHz communication, significantly new hardware technology is required at mm-wave. The frequency synthesizer is a critical sub-system that enables mm-wave transceivers to tune to a desired channel by precisely generating a tunable, clean "local oscillator (LO)" signal.

 

This project has developed mm-wave digital frequency synthesizers having the following attributes: (1) they generate signals with high spectral purity over ultra-wide tuning ranges, and (2) they feature a "digital-intensive" approach that enables the design to fully exploit the benefits of Moore's Law. An "all-digital" frequency synthesizer that successfully overcomes previously unsolved challenges and thus paves the way to achieve sufficiently high performance for mm-wave wireless communications has been demonstrated. The synthesizer is underpinned by the development of innovative architectures, circuits and calibration techniques. Key breakthroughs have been made in the constituent blocks including mm-wave digitally controlled oscillators, frequency dividers, time-to-digital converters of mm-wave digital synthesizers; and at the level of the synthesizer loop. The underlying concepts have been demonstrated by a series of prototypes that build up from the component level to a complete digital synthesizer. Characterization of these prototypes demonstrates record performance compared to the latest benchmarks in the literature in the constituent blocks and the overall synthesizer.

 

This project has had several broader impacts. First, the outcomes of this research have been disseminated through three conference papers, three archival journal papers, two focused technical workshops at major conferences and several invited seminars given by the PI at universities and companies. Second, in addition to mm-wave wireless communications, the concepts and techniques developed in this project can also be applied to frequency synthesizers required in high-speed wireline communications. Third, components from this research have been integrated into modules in courses taught by the PI. These include the development of a lab module on voltage controlled oscillator based frequency modulators in an introductory undergraduate microelectronics class, and lectures on phase-locked loops and their constituent blocks in a new graduate class on integrated circuit design for communication. Fourth, this project has provided partial support for the training of several students including six doctoral students, two masters students and several undergraduates.
